snippet: A blunt phone call from President Obama prompted Egyptian leaders to scramble Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington.
abstract: Egyptian leaders scramble to repair country’s alliance with Washington, following blunt phone call from Pres Obama; acknowledge they erred in their response to attack on the United States Embassy in Cairo by first seeking to appease anti-American domestic opinion without offering a robust condemnation of the violence; Obama warns Pres Mohamed Morsi that relations will be jeopardized if Egyptian authorities fail to protect American diplomats and stand more firmly against anti-American attacks.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, HELENE COOPER and MARK LANDLER
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, and Helene Cooper and Mark Landler from Washington. Mai Ayyad contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: A blunt phone call from President Obama prompted Egyptian leaders to scramble Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington.

headline.main: Egypt, Hearing From Obama, Moves to Heal Rift From Protests
headline.print_headline: Egypt, Hearing From Obama, Moves to Heal Rift From Protests

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
